ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to develop my own experiments and troubleshoot as issues arose with them.
A combination of experimental design, video-designing, and a brief overview of common experimental methods in archaeology.
More archaeology knowledge that built on what I learned in archaeology lab. Can definitely be taken in or out of major, and final project is a super engaging video assignment that you will LOVE!
I learned about how experimental archaeology is conducted and how what experimental archaeology has entailed in the past.
Skills in project and research planning
Ability to design my own experiment and reach out for raw materials, design an experiment in time and publicity-related skills to film my experiment and explain it well.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was taught very clearly and effectively. However, I believe the schedule could be improved upon. In the future, it would be helpful to begin our final projects and acquire the materials for them before Spring Break, so that there is more time at the end to produce a high-quality video.

This course gave students a lot of leeway in designing their own experiments, however I felt like I floundered a bit trying to figure out how to do my project. More direct help in designing an experiment in class may have been useful.
Prof Frahm is so amazing at teaching in a way that keeps sometimes dry information very engaging and fun. Would highly recommend!
The course was very fun and interesting and it allowed to students to share their ideas with each other very well. I think the class time couldve been shorter.
Timing for collecting project materials, preferably require materials be requested prior to spring break to ensure enough time to collect them upon returning
It will be helpful if we have material-based group sign up: eg. people want to do bones, stones, ceramics sign up together as respective groups and either work on the same or separate projects.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course for any student who wishes to learn more about experimental archaeology, or to develop their own experiments.

I would not recommend this course to students who are not planning on studying archaeology, though the topic is very interesting I think it is tailored to the discipline without a lot of transferable skills. I would recommend Introduction to Archaeological Lab Science - another course by the same professor - instead, as I felt it taught a similar topic (methods in archaeology) much more effectively.
Yes it was very fun and Im glad I took it.
Learned a lot and had a lot of fun!
Yes! Especially if you are looking for a fun class that you get to practice what you've learned
